TopicTitle: effect of meteors on atmospheric composition

Articles.Content: I know many meteors are remains of comets, meaning they probably have water and various other volatiles in them. How major of an affect would this have on the atmosphere over time?

This is something I've often wondered about. We have millions of pieces of debris floating around in LEO; what's going to be the cumulative effect of those things re-entering over the next few hundred years?

I'm trying to find data on the mass of dust and particle entering the atmosphere and I'm getting various numbers, about 40 000 80 000 tons per year.

By contrast, the mass of atmosphere is about 5 x 10^15 tons, so, even if you include billions of years of dust accumulation, the difference is still orders of magnitude.

In Red Mars they crashed an ice asteroid into Mars and it thickened the atmosphere fifty millibars. There was a lot of water vapour released in the impact and the ground in the crater was outgassing as well.
